title: Hugh of Saint-Cher
text:
Hugh of Saint-Cher (), <a href="Dominican%20Order">O.P.</a> (c. 1200 – 19 March 1263) was a <a href="French%20people">French</a> <a href="Dominican%20Order">Dominican</a> <a href="friar">friar</a> who became a <a href="cardinal%20%28Catholicism%29">cardinal</a> and noted <a href="Bible">biblical</a> commentator.
Life.
Hugh was born at Saint-Cher, a suburb of <a href="Vienne">Vienne</a>, <a href="Dauphin%C3%A9">Dauphiné</a>, around the beginning of the 13th century. After completing his early 
studies at a local monastery near his home, at about the age of fourteen, he went to the <a href="University%20of%20Paris">University of Paris</a> to study <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a>, <a href="theology">theology</a>, and <a href="jurisprudence">jurisprudence</a>, which latter subject he later taught in the same city.
In 1225, he entered the Dominican <a href="priory">priory</a> there and took the <a href="religious%20habit">religious habit</a> of the recently founded Order. Soon after his admission, he was appointed as <a href="provincial%20superior">Prior Provincial</a> of the Order for France. In 1230 he became Master of Theology and was elected prior of the Paris monastery. During those years, he contributed largely to the Order's success, and won the confidence of <a href="Pope%20Gregory%20IX">Pope Gregory IX</a>, who sent him as a <a href="papal%20legate">papal legate</a> to Constantinople in 1233.
Cardinalate.
<a href="Pope%20Innocent%20IV">Pope Innocent IV</a> made Hugh a <a href="Cardinal%20Priest">Cardinal Priest</a> in 1244, with his <a href="titular%20church">titular church</a> being <a href="Santa%20Sabina">Santa Sabina</a>, the mother church of the Dominican Order. He then played an important part in the <a href="First%20Council%20of%20Lyons">First Council of Lyons</a>, which took place the following year. He contributed to the institution of the <a href="Feast%20of%20Corpus%20Christi">Feast of Corpus Christi</a> on the <a href="General%20Roman%20Calendar">General Roman Calendar</a>. In 1247, upon instructions of Pope Innocent, Hugh revised the <a href="Carmelite%20Rule%20of%20St.%20Albert">Carmelite Rule of St. Albert</a>, which the <a href="beatification">Saint</a> <a href="Albert%20Avogadro">Albert Avogadro</a>, <a href="Latin%20Patriarch%20of%20Jerusalem">Latin Patriarch of Jerusalem</a>, had given the first <a href="Carmelites">Carmelite friars</a> on <a href="Mount%20Carmel">Mount Carmel</a>. The Holy See felt it necessary to mitigate some of the Rule's more demanding elements to make it more compatible with conditions in Europe. The same pope approved these changes, and this revision remains the Rule for the Carmelite Order. After the death in 1250 of the <a href="Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Holy Roman Emperor</a> <a href="Frederick%20II%2C%20Holy%20Roman%20Emperor">Frederick II</a>, Pope Innocent sent Hugh to Germany as his legate for the election of a successor.
Under the authority of <a href="Pope%20Alexander%20IV">Pope Alexander IV</a>, in 1255 Hugh supervised the commission that condemned the "Introductorius in Evangelium aeternum" of <a href="Gherardino%20da%20Borgo%20San%20Donnino">Gherardino da Borgo San Donnino</a>, which promoted the teachings of <a href="Abbot">Abbot</a> <a href="Joachim%20of%20Fiore">Joachim of Fiore</a>. These teachings worried the bishops as they had become widespread among the <a href="Fraticelli">"Spiritual"</a> wing of the Franciscan friars, to which Gherardino belonged.
He also supervised the condemnation of <a href="William%20of%20St%20Amour">William of St Amour</a>'s "De periculis novissimorum temporum". This work was an expression of the attack on the <a href="mendicant%20Orders">mendicant Orders</a>, who were becoming so successful in the lives of the universities, by the <a href="secular%20clergy">secular clergy</a> who had previously had unchallenged authority there. Hugh served as <a href="Apostolic%20Penitentiary">Major Penitentiary</a> of the Catholic Church from 1256 to 1262. He was named <a href="Cardinal%20Bishop%20of%20Ostia">Cardinal Bishop of Ostia</a> in December 1261, but resigned a few months later and returned to his title of Santa Sabina.
Hugh was in residence in <a href="Orvieto">Orvieto</a>, Italy, with <a href="Pope%20Urban%20IV">Pope Urban IV</a>, who had established a long-term residence there, when he died on 19 March 1263.
Works.
Hugh of St-Cher (or, possibly, a team of scholars under his direction) was the first to compile a so-called "correctorium", a collection of variant readings of the Bible. His work, entitled "Correctio Biblie", survives in more than a dozen manuscripts.
In the preface to the "Correctio Biblie", Hugh writes that he has collated various Latin versions and biblical commentaries, as well as the Hebrew manuscripts. For his approach to the text of the Bible, he was criciticsed by <a href="William%20de%20la%20Mare">William de la Mare</a>, author of another "correctorium".
His commentary on <a href="Peter%20Lombard">Peter Lombard</a>'s "<a href="Book%20of%20Sentences">Book of Sentences</a>" exercised significant influence over subsequent generations of theologians. The works introduced for the first time the distinction between God's unconditioned <a href="omnipotence">potence</a> (in <a href="Latin">Latin</a>: "potentia absoluta") and his conditioned one ("potentia conditionata"). The latter belongs to the divine kingship, but is also limited by the goodness and love of God, as well as by the law he had given to mankind. The distinction influenced the theology of <a href="John%20Duns%20Scotus">John Duns Scotus</a> who distinguished the unconditioned potence of God ("potentia absoluta") from the ordained potence ("potentia ordinata").
The distinction was forged in his commentary on the "Sentences". This new theological notion was rejected by <a href="William%20of%20Auxerre">William of Auxerre</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Aquinas">Thomas Aquinas</a>, <a href="Albert%20the%20Great">Albert the Great</a>, Saint <a href="Bonaventure">Bonaventure</a> and <a href="John%20of%20La%20Rochelle">John of La Rochelle</a>. <a href="William%20Courtenay">William Courtenay</a> (1342-1396) and Lawrence Moonan identified its origin in the "Summa Theologiae" of Geoffrey of Poitiers.
Hugh of Saint-Cher also wrote the "Postillae in sacram scripturam juxta quadruplicem sensum, litteralem, allegoricum, anagogicum et moralem," published frequently in the 15th and 16th centuries. His "Sermones de tempore et sanctis" are apparently only extracts. His <a href="exegesis">exegetical</a> works were published at <a href="Venice">Venice</a> in 1754 in eight volumes.
Hugh directed the compilation of the first <a href="Bible%20concordance">Bible concordance</a> (of the <a href="Vulgate">Vulgate</a>, completed in 1230.
